importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Original publication of the memoir in South Korea, which led to its widespread popularity and cultural impact.
English translation of the memoir released, leading to international acclaim and inclusion on global bestseller lists.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from 2018 to 2025 marks the rise and global influence of Baek Se-hee’s work, especially with the publication and international success of her memoirs.

keyTakeAways: Baek Se-hee, a South Korean author, died at age 35 after writing the bestselling memoir 'I Want to Die but I Want to Eat Tteokbokki'.
The memoir blends personal therapy reflections with mental health struggles, offering a candid look at depression and daily small joys.

The book became a cultural phenomenon in South Korea and gained international fame after being translated into English in 2022, reaching the Sunday Times Bestsellers List and receiving a New York Times recommendation.
Baek wrote a follow-up memoir in 2019 titled 'I Want to Die but I Still Want to Eat Tteokbokki,' documenting her ongoing battle with dysthymia, a chronic low-level depression.
She studied creative writing at university and began writing her memoir while working as a social media director at a publishing house during her depression treatment.
Baek Se-hee donated her heart, lungs, liver, and both kidneys, saving the lives of five people, as confirmed by the Korean Organ Donation Agency.
Her sister, Baek Da-hee, paid tribute to her as a compassionate, kind-hearted person who shared her heart through writing and hoped to nurture hope in others.
Anton Hur, her English translator and fellow author, praised her impact, stating that her writing reached millions and touched countless lives.

summaryOfNewsArticle: South Korean author Baek Se-hee, known for her deeply personal and honest memoirs on mental health, has died at age 35. Her bestselling book 'I Want to Die but I Want to Eat Tteokbokki' details her struggles with depression and dysthymia, juxtaposed with everyday joys like eating tteokbokki, a beloved South Korean street food. The memoir, first published in 2018, gained widespread popularity in South Korea and international acclaim after being translated into English in 2022, reaching the Sunday Times Bestsellers List and receiving a New York Times recommendation. She wrote a follow-up memoir in 2019 on her continued battle with chronic depression. Baek studied creative writing and began writing during her depression treatment at a publishing house. She donated her heart, lungs, liver, and both kidneys, saving five lives. Her sister and translator Anton Hur praised her legacy, emphasizing her compassion and profound impact on readers worldwide.
title: Baek Se-hee, author of bestselling memoir ‘I Want To Die But I Want To Eat Tteokbokki,’ dead at 35
